title: 105_hr3638
content: Preference for contractors hiring welfare recipients. In awarding federal contracts, preference is given to entities that agree to hire welfare recipients for the created jobs. The evaluation system increases the preference based on the number of welfare recipients hired. Exceptions apply for national security reasons or if no entry-level jobs are expected to be created. The section applies to contracts over $500,000 by federal agencies using competitive procedures. A welfare recipient is defined as someone receiving assistance under a state program funded by the Social Security Act. SEC. 2. ACCESS TO JOBS GRANTS. The Secretary of Transportation will provide grants to States to help transport welfare recipients to work and related activities. States receiving grants must then distribute the funds to state agencies, local authorities, and nonprofit organizations. Criteria for selecting grant recipients include the percentage of welfare recipients in the area and the need for transportation services. Coordination with other federal programs is required. The Secretary of Transportation will provide grants to States to help transport welfare recipients to work and related activities. Criteria for selecting grant recipients include the need for additional services to transport welfare recipients, coordination with existing transportation service providers, maximum utilization of existing providers, innovative approaches, and long-term financing strategies. The State may provide grants for capital projects, equipment, facilities, and transit vouchers for welfare recipients. Employer-provided transportation is also promoted. No planning or coordination activities are eligible for assistance. In 1986, no planning or coordination activities are eligible for assistance under this section. The Federal share of costs for a project shall not exceed 50 percent of the net project cost, with the remainder provided in cash from other sources. Funds from eligible Federal departments or agencies can be used for the nongovernment share. Planning requirements from title 49, United States Code, must be met for grants under this section. Coordination with affected transit grant recipients is necessary for project approval. The approval of transit grant recipients and projects must be part of a coordinated public transit-human services transportation planning process. Grants are subject to terms and conditions of section 5307 of title 49, United States Code. Funds are apportioned among states based on the amount paid under the Social Security Act. Program evaluation is conducted by the Comptroller General every six months. The Comptroller General and the Secretary are required to conduct studies to evaluate the access to jobs program under this section and report the results to specific committees in the House of Representatives and the Senate. Definitions for terms like capital project and urbanized area are provided in this section. The terms "capital project" and "urbanized area" are defined under section 5302 of title 49, United States Code. "Existing transportation service providers" refer to mass transportation operators, governmental agencies, and nonprofit organizations receiving assistance for nonemergency transportation services. A "welfare recipient" is an individual receiving aid under a State program funded under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. The Personal Responsibility and Work Opportunity Reconciliation Act of 1996 allows applicants to apply for grants under this section within a 3-year period. $500,000,000 per fiscal year is authorized for funding from 1999 to 2004, with the funds remaining available until expended. SEC. 3. GUARANTEES OF LOANS MADE BY STATES TO CURRENT OR RECENT WELFARE RECIPIENTS. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide loan guarantees to States up to $50,000,000 annually. The amount of guarantees per State is based on the ratio of funds payable under the Social Security Act. The Secretary of Health and Human Services may provide loan guarantees to States for loans made by the State to recipients of assistance under a State program funded under part A of title IV of the Social Security Act. The loan amount must be between $20 and $5,000, with interest not exceeding the rate on bonds issued by the smallest political subdivision in the borrower's State. The term "State" is defined as in the Social Security Act, and regulations will be established by the Secretary. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will prescribe necessary regulations for this section.
